entry.summary: 用 Steven Sinofsky 的话来说，把关是苹果对 iOS 品牌承诺的一个基本方面。
entry.content:
上周，我在拒绝开源 PC 模拟器 UTM SE 的背景下提到了苹果公司对 JIT（即时编译器）的禁止。 Apple 出于安全原因禁止 JIT 是 UTM SE 的一个附带问题，因为 UTM SE 是不使用 JIT 的 UTM 版本。但因为它不是 JIT，所以速度太慢，以至于UTM 团队认为不值得与 Apple 就其拒绝进行斗争。

不过，在禁止 JIT 的问题上，值得注意的是，当您启用锁定模式时，Apple 甚至会在 WebKit 中禁用自己可信的 JIT，Apple现在将其描述为“一种可选的极端保护，专为极少数人设计，因为他们是谁或他们做什么，可能会成为一些最复杂的数字威胁的个人目标。大多数人从来都不会成为这种性质的攻击的目标。”苹果此前将锁定模式描述为对“开发国家资助的雇佣间谍软件的私营公司”目标的保护，但最近放弃了“国家资助”的措辞。

Apple 是这样描述锁定模式对网页浏览的影响的：

网页浏览 - 某些复杂的网页技术被阻止，这可能会导致某些网站加载速度变慢或无法正常运行。此外，网络字体可能不会显示，并且图像可能会被替换为缺失的图像图标。

JavaScriptCore 的 JIT 解释器是“复杂的 Web 技术”之一。两年前，当 iOS 16 处于测试阶段时，Alexis Lours 做了一些基准测试，以衡量禁用 JIT 对 JavaScript 性能的影响（他还确定了在锁定模式下禁用的其他 WebKit 功能的一长串列表，我希望这个列表Apple 将发布并保持更新）。 Lours 运行了几个基准测试，但我怀疑 Speedometer 与现实世界的使用最相关：

Speedometer 旨在通过模拟多个框架上的页面操作来对现实世界的应用程序进行基准测试。这应该能让我们对 JavaScript 重型框架的性能下降有一个很好的了解。

性能下降 65%，虽然与 95% 的下降相比，这仍然对性能造成严重打击，但这将价值从不可行转变为值得寻求额外隐私的人们考虑的妥协方案。

这让我想到了BrowserEngineKit ，这是 Apple 专门为遵守欧盟 DMA 而创建的新框架，它需要把关平台允许第三方浏览器引擎。苹果十多年来一直允许第三方浏览器在 iOS 上运行，但要求所有浏览器都使用系统的 WebKit 渲染引擎。对于苹果公司长期以来禁止第三方渲染引擎的一种看法是，他们是在通过 Safari 来保护自己的利益。或多或少，他们只是在开玩笑。但这确实有一个安全角度。 JavaScript 引擎通过 JIT 编译运行得更快，但 JIT 本质上会带来安全挑战。 BrowserEngineKit 文档中有一个专门关于 JIT 编译的部分。

在我看来，从广义上讲，苹果有三种选择来遵守 DMA 中的第三方浏览器引擎指令：

  1. 禁止第三方浏览器引擎使用 JIT。任何真正想在 iOS 上看到基于 Chromium 或 Gecko 的浏览器的人显然都会认为这是恶意的。与 WebKit 相比，JavaScript 的执行速度会慢 65% 到 90%。

  2. 允许欧盟的第三方浏览器引擎不受限制地自由使用JIT编译。这将使运行此类浏览器的 iOS 设备面临安全漏洞。向用户传达的信息实际上是：“如果您使用其中一种浏览器，那么您就得靠自己了。”

  3. 创建像 BrowserEngineKit 这样的东西，它以允许以更安全的方式进行 JIT 编译（和其他潜在不安全的技术）的名义增加了复杂性，并将 BrowserEngineKit 的使用限制为仅受信任的 Web 浏览器开发人员。

苹果选择了选择 3，我怀疑他们是否认真考虑过其他任何事情。禁止第三方渲染引擎使用 JIT 是行不通的，而且允许它们随意运行也是不安全的。使用 BrowserEngineKit还需要特殊的权利：

苹果将​​为授权开发人员提供系统内技术的访问权限，这些技术可实现关键功能并帮助开发人员提供高性能的现代浏览器引擎。这些技术包括即时编译、多进程支持等等。

然而，由于浏览器引擎不断暴露于不可信和潜在的恶意内容，并且敏感用户数据可见，因此它们是不良行为者最常见的攻击媒介之一。为了帮助确保用户的在线安全，苹果只会授权开发人员在满足特定标准并承诺遵守一系列持续的隐私和安全要求（包括及时的安全更新以解决新出现的威胁和漏洞）后实施替代浏览器引擎。

BrowserEngineKit 并不容易，但我真的不认为有什么好的解决方案。浏览器不需要特殊的权限或复杂的框架就可以在 MacOS 上运行，这是事实，但 iOS 不是 MacOS。用 Steven Sinofsky 的话来说，把关是苹果对 iOS 品牌承诺的一个基本方面。

entry.title: ★ Apple 在锁定模式下禁用 WebKit 的 JIT，暗示了 BrowserEngineKit 为何复杂且受限

entry.summary: Apple 专注于在 Apple 设备上做其他人做不到的事情，甚至没有真正尝试与 ChatGPT *等人竞争世界知识背景。他们专注于独特的差异化，避免商品化。
entry.content:
一个广为人知的故事是，早在 2009 年，即 Dropbox 推出两年后，也就是苹果推出 iCloud 的前两年，史蒂夫·乔布斯邀请 Dropbox 联合创始人德鲁·休斯顿 (Drew Houston) 和阿拉什·费尔多西 (Arash Ferdowsi) 前往库比蒂诺，向他们推销将公司出售给苹果的事宜。 乔布斯告诉他们，Dropbox 是“一项功能，而不是一个产品”。

如今，人们很容易忘记 Dropbox 是一款多么革命性的产品。只需在 Mac 和 Boom 上进行简单安装，您就拥有了一个在您使用的每台 Mac 之间自动、可靠且快速同步的文件夹。当时 Dropbox 在其总部有一个大标牌，上面简单地写着“It Just Works”，他们实现了这一理想——当时没有其他同步服务可以做到这一点。当然，乔布斯试图说服休斯顿和菲尔多西出售，但这并不意味着他错了，最终，这是一个功能，而不是一个产品。这是一个非常有用的功能，但仍然是一个功能。

在上周的 WWDC 之前，我一直在想同样的描述也适用于法学硕士生成式人工智能。非常有用，有时甚至令人惊叹，但是功能。不是产品。或者至少不是广泛通用的产品。当然，聊天机器人是产品。人们为获得其中最好的内容或延长使用它们而付费。但人们也会为 Dropbox 付费。

聊天机器人可能很有用。人们通过它们做出了令人惊叹的工作。但它们类似于终端和命令行工具。大多数人只是不这么想。

苹果上周通过Apple Intelligence推出的并不是新产品，而是由生成式 AI 驱动的现有产品的大量新功能。

苹果浏览器？现在更好了，有了生成式人工智能页面摘要。消息？与 Genmoji 一起享受更多乐趣。笔记、邮件和页面（以及使用系统文本框架的任何其他应用程序）？现在更好了，内置了校对和重写工具。相片？更好的记忆推荐，以及将照片自动分类到智能收藏中。西里？那个令人沮丧、 愚蠢透顶的王八蛋，Siri？也许，实际上，现在非常有用并且有点聪明。这些不是新应用程序或新产品。它们是苹果公司制作的最常用、最重要的应用程序，是定义苹果平台生态系统的核心应用程序，苹果公司正在使用生成式人工智能来使它们变得更好、更有用——但不会以任何方式让它们变得陌生。 1

我们对苹果在 WWDC 上的生成式人工智能战略有很多疑问。现在我们已经有了答案，一切看起来都非常明显，而且大部分都很简单。首先，他们的模型几乎完全基于个人上下文，通过设备上的语义索引。从广义上讲，这种设备上的语义索引可以被视为下一代 Spotlight。 Apple 专注于在 Apple 设备上做其他人做不到的事情，甚至没有真正尝试与 ChatGPT等公司竞争。对于世界知识背景。他们专注于独特的差异化，避免商品化。

其次，他们既针对较小/更简单的任务进行设备上处理，又针对更复杂的任务进行云处理（名为“私有云计算”）。所有这一切完全是苹果自己的工作：模型、服务器（基于苹果芯片）、服务器上运行的整个软件堆栈以及服务器所在的数据中心。这是一项巨大的工作量，而且似乎揭穿了有关 Apple 高管 18 个月前才对生成式 AI 产生兴趣的报道的谎言。如果他们确实在短短 18 个月内完成了这一切，那将是一项了不起的成就。

任何人都可以制作聊天机器人。 （而且，似乎每个人都在——在 App Store 中搜索“聊天机器人”与搜索“游戏”一样有用。） 值得注意的是，苹果还没有开发出一款机器人。本尼迪克特·埃文斯敏锐地观察到：

首先：苹果已经建立了一个没有聊天机器人的法学硕士。 Apple 已经构建了自己的基础模型，（根据其发布的基准）可与市场上的其他任何模型相媲美，但是您无法将原始提示直接插入模型并获取原始输出 - 总是有集合按钮和选项决定您的要求，并针对不同的功能以不同的方式呈现给用户。在大多数这些功能中，根本没有可见的机器人。您不会提出问题并得到答复：相反，您的电子邮件会被优先处理，或者您按“摘要”并会出现摘要。你可以在 Siri 中输入请求（Siri 本身只是使用 Apple 模型的众多功能之一），但即便如此，你也无法得到原始模型输出：你得到的是 GUI。 LLM 被抽象为 API 调用。

相反，苹果正在做其他人无法做到的事情：将生成式人工智能集成到开发人员用来创建本机应用程序的 iOS 和 MacOS 框架中。基于系统 API 和框架构建的应用程序将免费获得生成式 AI 功能，既指当应用程序在满足 Apple Intelligence 资格的最低规格的设备上运行时，这些功能会自动生成，也指 Apple 的不会向开发者或用户收取使用这些功能的费用。

苹果公司的主题演讲结构严谨、节奏紧凑。但尽管如此，我怀疑它还是被广泛误解了，因为人们的期望是错误的。那些认为苹果在生成人工智能技术方面远远落后于最先进技术的人错误地看到了主题演讲的尾声——宣布与 OpenAI 合作，将他们的最新模型 ChatGPT-4o 集成为可选的“世界知识”层坐在苹果自己开发的 Apple Intelligence 之上——这表明苹果展示的大部分甚至全部炫酷功能实际上都是由 OpenAI 提供支持的。恰恰相反。苹果在主题演讲中展示的几乎所有内容都不是来自 OpenAI。

我认为主要的收获是：

  • Apple 继续在其核心平台 iOS 和 MacOS 上构建机器学习和生成式 AI 功能。他们多年来一直在添加此类功能，并于今年宣布了许多新功能。苹果在主题演讲的整个第一个小时内宣布的任何内容都不是“苹果智能”的一部分。 数学笔记（Apple Notes 和计算器应用程序中的自由手写或打字数学，最终登陆 iPadOS）将登陆所有运行 iOS 18 和 MacOS 15 Sequoia 的设备。 Smart Script——使用 Apple Pencil 时的全新个性化手写功能，旨在提高书写时手写内容的易读性，并在粘贴文本或在数学笔记中生成答案时模拟您的手写内容——即将登陆所有 A14 或更高版本的 iPad芯片。所有设备上的 Apple Mail 都将提供收件箱分类和智能邮件摘要功能。 Safari 网页摘要即将支持所有设备。更好的视频会议背景剪辑（“绿屏”）。这些功能都不属于“Apple Intelligence”范畴。它们适用于所有拥有符合今年操作系统版本要求的设备的人。

  • Apple Intelligence 的最低设备规格是可以理解的，但令人遗憾的是，特别是当前唯一符合资格的 iPhone 是 iPhone 15 Pro 和 Pro Max。即使是仅上市 9 个月的 iPhone 15 机型也未能上榜。当我上周在 The Talk Show Live 的舞台上向 John Giannandrea（以及 Craig Federighi 和 Greg Joswiak）询问此事时，他的回答很简单：较小的设备速度不够快，无法提供良好的体验。这就是苹果的方式：根本不提供该功能比提供糟糕（缓慢）的体验更好。去年的 A17 Pro 之前的 A 系列芯片没有足够的 RAM ，也没有足够强大的神经引擎。但当 Apple Intelligence 功能真正可用时——即使是 Beta 版（在当前的开发者操作系统 Beta 版中尚未启用）——iPhone 15 Pro 肯定会被所有 iPhone 16 机型（包括 Pro 和非 Pro）加入。 Apple Intelligence 正在滑向几年后的目标，而不是现在的位置。

  • 当然，苹果对设备要求也很挑剔，以减轻其云计算服务器的负载。如果这促使更多人今年升级到新 iPhone，我怀疑蒂姆·库克是否会认为这是一个问题。

  • 我经常被问到的一个问题是，为什么不符合 Apple Intelligence 资格的设备不能通过私有云计算完成所有操作。每个人都明白，如果设备的速度或功能不足以进行设备上的处理，那就是这样。但是，为什么旧​​款 iPhone（或者非专业版 iPhone 15、配备两年前芯片的新 iPhone）不能简单地使用私有云计算来处理所有事情呢？据我所知，这并不是 Apple Intelligence 的设计初衷。在设备上运行的模型与在云中运行的模型完全不同，其中一种设备上模型是启发式模型，用于确定哪些任务可以通过设备上处理执行以及哪些任务需要私有云计算或 ChatGPT 。但是，另请参阅此列表中的前一项——苹果肯定也有扩展问题。就目前情况而言，只有使用 M 系列芯片或 A17 或更高版本芯片的设备才符合资格，苹果将通过私有云计算进行大量服务器端计算。如果他们为旧款 iPhone 启用 Apple Intelligence，而这些旧款 iPhone 不会在设备上进行任何处理，那么他们将面临数倍的损失。 Apple Intelligence 的设备上处理组件不仅是可有可无的，而且是整个事情的基石。

  • 苹果本可以跳过整个 OpenAI 合作伙伴关系，或者干脆推迟到秋季宣布整个 OpenAI 合作伙伴关系，但他们仍然会拥有一系列令人印象深刻的具有广泛实用吸引力的生成式 AI 功能。显然，在主题演讲结束后，他们的成就会得到更多的认可。我仍然怀疑在操作系统级别集成 ChatGPT（以及任何未来的世界知识 LLM 聊天机器人合作伙伴）是否会给用户带来任何重大的实际优势，而不是仅仅使用这些 LLM 制造商的聊天机器人应用程序。但也许删除一些步骤，并消除选择、下载和注册第三方聊天机器人的需要，将使这些功能向比目前使用它们的更多用户开放。但我不禁觉得，将这些第三方聊天机器人集成到操作系统中至少既是一种服务收入游戏，也是一种用户体验游戏。

  • Apple Intelligence 最不为人知的方面是，Apple 为私有云计算构建的数据中心不仅是碳中和的，而且完全依靠可再生能源运行。这是非凡的，我相信在整个行业中是独一无二的。但它基本上没有引起人们的注意——因为苹果自己在 WWDC 主题演讲中没有提到这一点。 Craig Federighi在 Justine Ezarik 的主题演讲后采访中首次提到了这一点，他在WWDC 脱口秀现场的舞台上与我重申了这一点。事后看来，我希望我在台上问为什么苹果在主题演讲中甚至没有提到这一点，更不用说宣扬它了。我怀疑真正的答案是，苹果觉得他们不能在宣布与 OpenAI 合作的同一活动中吹嘘自己的数据中心完全依靠可再生能源运行，而 OpenAI 的数据中心却不能做出这样的声明。 OpenAI 的碳足迹是一个秘密，专家怀疑这很糟糕。将自己的合作伙伴扔到公共汽车下是不合时宜的，但这使得苹果智能公司宣布的碳中和作为一个营销点不再被考虑。我认为苹果上周不宣布这一合作关系可能会更好的另一个原因。

  • 如果您不想或不信任 Apple Intelligence（或只是还没有），您可以将其关闭。您必须选择使用集成的 ChatGPT 功能，并且每次 Apple Intelligence 决定将您发送到 ChatGPT 来处理任务时，您都必须明确允许。按照目前的设计，没有人会意外地与 ChatGPT 交互，更不用说向 ChatGPT 暴露个人信息了。如果有什么的话，我怀疑更常见的抱怨将来自那些每次都希望使用 ChatGPT 而不进行确认的人。有些人想要一个“始终允许”选项来将请求传递给 ChatGPT，但据我采访过的 Apple 代表称，这样的选项尚不存在。

  • 在技​​术层面上，Apple 正在使用间接方式对 ChatGPT 中的设备进行匿名化。 OpenAI 永远不会看到您的 IP 地址或精确位置。在政策层面，OpenAI 同意不存储用户数据，也不将数据用于培训目的，除非用户已登录 ChatGPT 帐户。如果您想使用 Apple Intelligence 但不想使用 ChatGPT，也可以。如果您想匿名使用 ChatGPT，也可以。如果您确实希望 ChatGPT 保留您的互动历史记录，您也可以通过登录您的帐户来实现。用户拥有完全的控制权，这是他们应该做的。

  • 尽管 Vision Pro 配备了 M2 芯片，但 VisionOS 2 并未获得任何 Apple Intelligence 功能。原因之一是 VisionOS 仍然是一个令人惊叹的新平台——苹果仍在忙于构建基础功能，比如在主视图中重新排列和组织应用程序。 VisionOS 2 甚至没有像数学笔记这样的功能，正如我上面提到的，它甚至不在苹果智能保护伞之下。但另一个原因是，据消息灵通的小鸟透露，Vision Pro 已经大量使用 M2 的神经引擎来补充 R1 芯片，以实现实时处理目的——遮挡和物体检测等。对于配备 M 系列的 Mac 和 iPad，神经引擎基本上就在那里，完全可用于 Apple Intelligence 功能。 Vision Pro 已经投入使用。

  • “苹果智能”不是一件事或一种模型。甚至两种模型——本地模型和云模型。它涵盖了数十种模型，其中一些模型非常具体。其中最好的可能是一种新模型，它可以让 Siri 回答有关苹果产品和服务的技术支持问题。该模型已在 Apple 自己的丰富支持文档知识库上进行了训练。古老的抱怨是“没有人阅读文档”，但也许现在这不再是问题，因为 Siri 正在阅读它。苹果的平台如此丰富和深入，但大多数用户对它们的了解却很肤浅；从 Siri 获得具体操作问题的正确答案可能会改变游戏规则。人工智能生成的垃圾正在污染寻求技术帮助的网络搜索结果；苹果正在使用根据自己的文档进行训练的有针对性的人工智能，以避免首先搜索网络的需要。技术文档并不性感，但通过自然语言查询将其全部公开可能是今年公告中的热门产品之一。

  • Xcode 是苹果在生成人工智能功能方面明显落后的一款产品。去年，它在法学硕士支持的代码完成/建议/帮助方面落后了。 Apple在 Xcode 16 中引入了两项生成式 AI 功能，它们总体上体现了 Apple Intelligence 中本地/云的区别。预测代码完成在您的 Mac 上本地运行。 Swift Assist 更加深刻，可以回答自然语言问题并在工作 Swift 代码中提供完整的解决方案，并且完全在私有云计算中运行。

对这一切持保留态度

最后，需要注意的是，我们还无法尝试任何 Apple Intelligence 功能。它们都还没有在开发者操作系统测试版中可用，而且即使在测试版中，也预计要到“今年夏天晚些时候”才能使用。上周，在主题演讲结束后在 Apple Park 举行的新闻发布会上，我目睹了其中一些功能的多个现场演示。我目睹的演示包括书写工具（“让这封电子邮件听起来更专业”）以及 Xcode 代码完成和 Swift Assist。但这些演示是由苹果员工进行的；我们媒体人无法亲自尝试。

这一切看起来非常令人印象深刻，而且几乎所有这些功能看起来都很实用。但这一切都还非常非常早。在我们自己能够使用之前，它们都不算真实。我们不知道它的效果如何。我们不知道它的扩展能力如何。

如果生成式人工智能不被认为是必不可少的——无论是在消费者营销还是投资者信心方面——我认为苹果在“Apple Intelligence”中发布的大部分内容（如果不是大部分的话）甚至要到明年的WWDC 才会公布，而不是上周的 WWDC。再说一遍，“Apple Intelligence”中的所有功能都还没有提供测试版，我认为所有或大部分功能在明年之前都只能在“测试版”标签下提供。

不过，很高兴看到苹果公司的努力。我仍然认为，总体而言，将苹果视为生成式人工智能“落后”的说法是错误的。但显然他们在这方面感受到了巨大的竞争压力，这对他们有好处，对我们也有好处。

entry.summary: 公共网络的全部意义在于，即使学习者不是人类，也可以从中学习。是否有一个法学硕士“未”在公共网络上接受过培训？据我所知，不存在这种情况，而且一个不了解公共网络上所有可用信息的模型将是对世界非常无知的。
entry.content:
昨天，引用 Anthropic 宣布的令人印象深刻的新模型 Claude 3.5 Sonnet，我写道：

另外，从帖子的底部，这个有趣的金块：

指导我们人工智能模型开发的核心宪法原则之一是隐私。除非用户明确允许我们这样做，否则我们不会根据用户提交的数据来训练我们的生成模型。迄今为止，我们尚未使用任何客户或用户提交的数据来训练我们的生成模型。

连苹果都不敢这么说。

现在看来我显然误读了 Anthropic 的声明。我错误地将此解释为暗示克劳德没有接受过公共网络数据的培训。 以下是 Anthropic 关于训练数据的常见问题解答：

像 Claude 这样的大型语言模型需要在文本上进行“训练”，以便它们能够学习单词之间的模式和联系。这种训练很重要，这样模型才能有效、安全地运行。

虽然我们无意专门针对个人数据“训练”我们的模型，但与其他模型一样，我们的大型语言模型的训练数据可以包括基于网络的数据，这些数据可能包含公开的个人数据。我们使用来自三个来源的数据来训练我们的模型：

  1. 通过互联网公开获取的信息
  2. 我们从第三方企业许可的数据集
  3. 我们的用户或众包工作者提供的数据

我们采取措施，通过培训过程尽量减少对个人隐私的影响。我们按照严格的政策和准则运营，例如，我们不会访问受密码保护的页面或绕过验证码控制。我们对我们许可的数据进行尽职调查。我们鼓励用户不要使用我们的产品和服务来处理个人数据。此外，我们的模型经过训练，尊重隐私：我们的宪法“原则”是克劳德的核心，基于《世界人权宣言》，是选择最尊重每个人的隐私、独立、声誉、家庭的回应、产权和结社权。

以下是苹果公司上周发布的设备和服务器基础模型：

我们根据许可数据训练我们的基础模型，包括为增强特定功能而选择的数据，以及我们的网络爬虫 AppleBot 收集的公开数据。网络发布商可以选择不使用其网络内容进行 Apple Intelligence 培训，并进行数据使用控制。

在训练我们的基础模型时，我们从不使用用户的私人个人数据或用户交互，并且我们应用过滤器来删除互联网上公开的个人身份信息，例如社会保障和信用卡号。我们还过滤脏话和其他低质量内容，以防止其包含在训练语料库中。除了过滤之外，我们还执行数据提取、重复数据删除以及应用基于模型的分类器来识别高质量文档。

这使得 Apple 在使用网络上的公共页面作为培训源方面与 Anthropic 处于同一位置。一些作家和创作者对此表示反对——包括 Federico Viticci ，他在 MacStories 上的文章我与昨天的“连苹果都不能这么说”的评论相关联。 Dan Moren 写了一篇很好的介绍，介绍了如何使用 robots.txt 指令阻止这些爬行机器人。

反对苹果使用公共网页进行模型训练的最佳论据是，他们首先进行了训练，但只是在上周宣布 Apple Intelligence 发布了阻止 Applebot 用于 AI 训练目的的指令之后。苹果应该澄清他们是否计划在今年夏天 Apple Intelligence 发布测试版之前重新索引用于训练的公共数据。显然，禁止 Applebot-Extended 的网站不应将其数据放入 Apple 的训练语料库中，仅仅因为 Applebot 在 Apple Intelligence 发布之前就抓取了该数据。公共数据在选择退出的基础上被排除，而不是包含在选择加入的数据中，这是公平的，但苹果在允许选择退出之前在公共网络上训练了其模型。

但除了先有鸡还是先有蛋的选择退出问题之外，我并不反对这一点。公共网络的全部意义在于，即使学习者不是人类，也可以从中学习。是否有一个法学硕士没有在公共网络上接受过培训？据我所知，不存在这种情况，而且一个不了解公共网络上所有可用信息的模型将是对世界非常无知的。对我来说，法学硕士的标准应该与我们要求人们遵守的标准类似。你可以自由地学习我发布的任何内容，但不能自由地抄袭它。如果您引用它，请注明来源并链接。这也是我对人工智能机器人的标准。所以目前，我的 robots.txt 文件仅禁止一项：Perplexity。

（如果我能弄清楚怎么做的话，我会阻止Arc 的伪君子们。）

entry.content:
伊恩·贝特奇（Ian Betteridge） ：

那么，苹果，Apple Intelligence违反了DMA的哪些位？因为除非您实际上可以告诉我们 - 在哪种情况下，我们显然对您对其运作方式提出的某些主张有一些问题 - 或者您在谈论胡说八道，而只是试图与欧盟获得一些杠杆作用。蒂姆是哪个？

我绝对保证人们会吞下这种“嗯，您不能借助DMA使Apple Intelligence起作用！！”线没有真正问任何违法的问题，因为“苹果说的话，他们不说谎”

那是苹果的全部要点。他们不知道。设计不确定。 EC支持者一直告诉我，这是一个与美国不同的特征，而不是一个虫子，是欧盟至关重要的法律的精神，而不是律法。因此，如果DMA中没有一个单词不允许核心技术费用，那也没关系。欧洲委员会决定违背DMA的精神，因此他们将要充电和苹果。

即将召开的竞赛负责人玛格丽特·维斯塔格（Margrethe Vestager）（她的10年任期将于11月到期）在本周对CNBC的Silvia Amaro进行了20分钟的采访，她反复威胁苹果，从13:00大关开始。

Vestager：我们有许多Apple问题；我发现他们非常严肃。我很惊讶我们会怀疑苹果是不合规的。它们非常重要，因为很多好的业务都是通过应用商店发生的，是通过付款机制发生的，因此，即使您知道我可以说这不是这样的公司的期望，但我们当然会准确地执行与任何其他业务相同的头等大事。 [...]我对《数字市场法》的看法是，我们越来越接近商业模式。 DMA要求的变化是将触动业务模型的变化。

Amaro：分手甚至分手？

vestager：嗯，还​​有待观察。但是，如果您必须携带第二家应用商店，那将在您自己的应用商店中造成凹痕。如果您无法宣传自己的服务，但需要为竞争对手腾出空间，当然，合法的是，这可能会带来一些自己的利润。因此，当然，这将是一项非常艰巨的执行任务，但即使是更加有意义的，因为对大型技术的竞争对手的潜力 - 它们确实非常非常大 - 这就是为什么执行DMA是当务之急的原因。

Amaro：我也出现苹果的原因是因为Spotify等公司还提出了苹果提出的新变化的问题，最终他们现在面临的账单是相同甚至更大的前。这就是为什么我想再次提出问题，即DMA是否实际上导致了大型技术的最终变化？还是他们仍然躲在这里，在某些...之间，在法律中？

vestager：嗯，我认为您在案件之前和最终确定案件之前都无法判断DMA，因为我们有一个罚款工具箱，罚款加倍，潜在的公司分手 - 因此我们有一个非常强大的惩罚工具箱。

entry.title: Open Source PC Emulator UTM Blocked by Apple for Notarization, Including Through EU Marketplaces
entry.content:
Michael Tsai:

This is confusing, but I think what Apple is saying is that, even with notarization, apps are not allowed to “download executable code.” Rule 2.5.2 says apps may not “download, install, or execute code” except for limited educational purposes. Rule 4.7 makes an exception to this so that retro game emulators and some other app types can run code “that is not embedded in the binary.” This is grayed out when you select “Show Notarization Review Guidelines Only”, meaning that the exception only applies within the App Store. Thus, the general prohibition remains in effect for App Marketplaces and Web Distribution. But it seems like this wasn't initially clear to Apple, either, because the review process took two months .

This also seems inconsistent with the fact that the Delta emulator is allowed to be notarized outside the App Store. It doesn't make much sense for the rules to be more lax within the App Store. I first thought the mistake was that Apple didn't mean to gray out 4.7 for notarization. Then everything would make sense. But the clarification states that 4.7 is not intended to apply to notarization.

The bottom line for me is that Apple doesn't want general-purpose emulators, it's questionable whether the DMA lets it block them, and even siding with Apple on this it isn't consistently applying its own rules.

Confusing indeed. Apple's stance on this seems inscrutable and arbitrary: retro game emulators are, at long last , acceptable, but general PC emulators are not. Such arbitrary policy decisions related to the purpose of the app are fine for the App Store (legally speaking), but clearly not compliant with the DMA. That's one of the few areas where the DMA is clear. Apple can, of course, ban (say) porno apps from the App Store, but can't refuse to notarize them for distribution outside the App Store in the EU.

Apple has a security leg to stand on when it comes to JIT compilation , but the version of UTM (UTM SE) that was held up in review for two months, and ultimately rejected by Apple, doesn't use a JIT . And because it doesn't use a JIT , performance is poor; hence the UTM developers' deeming it not worth fighting about . Apple goes into depth on the security challenges pertaining to JIT compilation in its documentation for BrowserEngineKit , the framework for developing non-WebKit browser engines for distribution in the EU. That's ostensibly the reason why developers need a special entitlement to use a custom browser engine — JavaScript engines need a JIT to perform well but JITs pose a security risk.

In an earlier revision of this post, I suggested that Delta — Riley Testut's excellent and wildly popular retro Nintendo console emulator for iOS — uses a JIT. There is indeed a JIT in Delta's source code repository , but Testut informs me that it's currently only enabled through the version of AltStore distributed through sideloading . Delta's JIT is removed from the versions of Delta in the App Store and AltStore PAL (the EU app marketplace), because of Apple's restrictions on JIT compilers. No app with a JIT is going to pass review by Apple, including for distribution outside the App Store in the EU. That restriction should, in theory, be permitted under the DMA on security grounds. But how the no-JIT version of UTM could be rejected for notarization, I do not see.

(Thinking about BrowserEngineKit makes me wonder: Now that over four months have passed since Apple announced its initial DMA compliance plans, has even a single browser developer announced plans to bring their own rendering engine to iOS in the EU? As far as I know the answer is no. It's entirely possible Apple went to all the trouble of creating BrowserEngineKit for compliance with the DMA, but no one is actually going to use it because no browser developer deems the EU market worth forking their browser for, solely for distribution outside the App Store — while on the hook for the 50-euro-cents-per-download Core Technology Fee if such a browser becomes popular.)

entry.title: Apple Security Research: 'Private Cloud Compute: A New Frontier for AI Privacy in the Cloud'
entry.content:
苹果：

We designed Private Cloud Compute to ensure that privileged access doesn't allow anyone to bypass our stateless computation guarantees.

First, we intentionally did not include remote shell or interactive debugging mechanisms on the PCC node. Our Code Signing machinery prevents such mechanisms from loading additional code, but this sort of open-ended access would provide a broad attack surface to subvert the system's security or privacy. Beyond simply not including a shell, remote or otherwise, PCC nodes cannot enable Developer Mode and do not include the tools needed by debugging workflows.

Next, we built the system's observability and management tooling with privacy safeguards that are designed to prevent user data from being exposed. For example, the system doesn't even include a general-purpose logging mechanism. Instead, only pre-specified, structured, and audited logs and metrics can leave the node, and multiple independent layers of review help prevent user data from accidentally being exposed through these mechanisms. With traditional cloud AI services, such mechanisms might allow someone with privileged access to observe or collect user data.

Many details here, but many still to come.

The September 2023 MGM hack quickly became one of the most notorious ransomware attacks in recent memory. Journalists and cybersecurity experts rushed to report on the broken slot machines, angry hotel guests, and the fateful phishing call to MGM's help desk that started it all.

And, like a slick magic trick, the public's attention was drawn in the wrong direction. Now, months later, we're still missing something critical about the MGM hack.

That's because, for many of the most important questions about the breach, the popular answers are either incomplete or inaccurate. Those include: who hacked MGM, what tactics they used to breach the system, and how security teams can protect themselves against similar attacks.

Why is that a problem? Because it lets us write off the MGM hack as a one-off story, instead of an example of an emerging style of attack that we'll certainly be seeing more of. And that leaves companies and security teams unprepared.

Who hacked MGM?

Plenty of news stories have confidently blamed the MGM attack on either the Scattered Spider or ALPHV hacking group, but the truth is still murky, and likely involves a dangerous team up between different groups, each bringing their own expertise to the table.

Their attacks first use fluent English social engineering skills to get onto networks, where they then deploy sophisticated ransomware that quickly establishes persistence across multiple systems.

What tactics did they use?

The dominant narrative has been that “ a single phone call hacked MGM.” A phone vishing attack to MGM's IT help desk is what started the hack, but there's much more to it than that. The real issue is that this help desk worker was set up to fail by MGM's weak ID verification protocols, and probably wasn't doing anything “wrong” when they gave the bad actors access to a super administrator account.

How can security teams protect themselves?

Cybersecurity experts have centered most of their advice on user ID verification. But while it's true that MGM's help desk needed better ways of verifying employee identity, there's another factor that should have stopped the hackers in their tracks.

That's where you need to focus your attention. In fact, if you just focus your vision, you'll find you're already staring at the security story the pros have been missing.

It's the device you're reading this on.

To read more of what we learned when we researched the MGM hack — like how hacker groups get their names, the worrying gaps in MGM's security, and why device trust is the real core of the story — check out the Kolide by 1Password Blog .

entry.title: Financial Times Reports EC to Charge Apple With Non-Compliance Under DMA for CTF
entry.content:
Javier Espinoza reporting from Brussels, and Michael Acton from San Francisco, for the Financial Times ( archive link in case your FT subscription isn't working):

The European Commission has determined that the iPhone maker is not complying with obligations to allow app developers to “steer” users to offers outside its App Store without imposing fees on them, according to three people with close knowledge of its investigation. The charges would be the first brought against a tech company under the Digital Markets Act, landmark legislation designed to force powerful “online gatekeepers” to open up their businesses to competition in the EU.

The commission, the EU's executive arm, said in March it was investigating Apple, as well as Alphabet and Meta, under powers granted by the DMA. An announcement over the charges against Apple was expected in the coming weeks, said two people with knowledge of the case. [...]

If found to be breaking the DMA, Apple faces daily penalties for non-compliance of up to 5 per cent of its average daily worldwide turnover, which is currently just over $1bn.

The EC leaks everything to the Financial Times. Reuters points out that EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager leaves office in November. Makes me wonder if there's a clock-running-out aspect to this. Does the incoming regime share her politics regarding US tech companies?

Forget about trying to figure out what the EC wants from reading the DMA.它没有说。 I suspect they want Apple to completely forgo monetization of its IP on iOS — to allow the distribution of iOS apps without any charge or fee whatsoever other than the $99 annual developer program fee. I'm not sure, at all, how Apple is going to respond, but I do not think the EC is going to get that. I also don't think they're ever going to collect any significant fines from Apple.

My basic theory is that what the EC has wanted all along is to force Apple not merely to open up iOS to other methods of distribution, but to force Apple to allow apps to be distributed through those non-App-Store channels free of charge. But they don't want to come out and say, flatly, that they seek to forbid Apple from monetizing its IP from all developers on the platform, because that's so radically anti-capitalist. So instead they wrote the DMA to forbid the way Apple had, heretofore, mandated its cut of App Store revenue, and I suspect they somehow thought that if they banned the current rules — all apps must go through the App Store, all apps must use Apple's App Store payment processing — then Apple would be forced to allow free-of-charge distribution through other channels and other payment processing. They didn't foresee the Core Technology Fee as a route to collect a cut from any and all popular applications distributed by large commercial developers. So they're just going to say that's not allowed either, even though it seemingly doesn't violate anything in the DMA. I don't know where this winds up because I don't see Apple conceding this point.

Not just shooting this event in 3D, but also streaming it live, was entirely the initiative of my dear friend, Mr. Sandwich himself, Adam Lisagor . I was asked a few times this week whether it was Apple who wanted to stream this live in 3D for viewing on Vision Pro.没有。 It was Adam who pitched me on the idea, only about eight weeks ago. I was like, “Well, sure, that sounds awesome, but how in the world would we do that? What camera could we use to shoot with? How would we stream it? What app would people be able to view it in? It's a great idea but none of this seems possible.” Adam was like “I think we can do it.”

And, son of a bitch, they did it.

Once I started talking with Apple about arranging for guests, we did let them know our plans to shoot and livestream in 3D for viewing in Theater on Vision Pro — an app that, at the time, was in early beta. Maybe even alpha. Apple's reaction echoed my own: sounds great but how ?

The how is a long story and I get zero credit for any of it, but it involves a custom camera rig with two Lumix BGH1 cameras , each with Olympus 17mm PRO prime ƒ/1.2 lenses (35mm equivalent field of view with the BGH1's Micro Four Thirds sensor). The lenses were about 3 inches apart — as close as possible — and microphones were placed throughout the theater to capture spatial audio.

The results exceeded my expectations, and I think everyone else's as well.

To be clear, we shot the show two entirely different ways. The standard multi-camera cut on YouTube, embedded above, was shot exactly as we've done in previous years. That video turned out great too. The 3D version in the Theater app was shot from a single point of view, roughly simulating the perspective from a front-row center seat in front of the stage. It looks cool and sounds even better. If you have a Vision Pro or access to one, I highly encourage you to check it out.

We're describing it as “3D video with spatial audio”, not “spatial video”, because that's a more precise description of the effect. True spatial video would be more immersive — “Look left to see Joz, look right to see Gruber” — and the effect we achieved wasn't quite like that. But what we did get is immersive, and very compelling. To the best of my knowledge, this was the first event livestreamed in 3D for viewing in VisionOS, and while my role was simply as the host of the show, that's pretty damn cool. I'm just amazed at what Lisagor and his team at Sandwich (and SpatialGen) were able to pull off in a matter of weeks.

entry.title: Gurman: Neither Apple Nor OpenAI Are Paying for Partnership
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, writing at Bloomberg * :

Left unanswered on Monday: which company is paying the other as part of a tight collaboration that has potentially lasting monetary benefits for both. But, according to people briefed on the matter, the partnership isn't expected to generate meaningful revenue for either party — at least at the outset.

The arrangement includes weaving ChatGPT, a digital assistant that responds in plain terms to information requests, into Apple's Siri and new writing tools. Apple isn't paying OpenAI as part of the partnership, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the deal terms are private. Instead, Apple believes pushing OpenAI's brand and technology to hundreds of millions of its devices is of equal or greater value than monetary payments, these people said.

Meanwhile, Apple, thanks to OpenAI, gets the benefit of offering an advanced chatbot to consumers — potentially enticing users to spend more time on devices or even splash out on upgrades.

Apple getting this free of charge, in exchange only for the prestige of showing the ChatGPT logo and credit to users of Apple devices who engage the integration, is the Apple-iest negotiation in recent memory. My money says Eddy Cue, Steve Jobs's favorite co-negotiator, made the deal. (I'd love to take Eddy Cue with me to the dealer when next I buy a car.)

During my show Tuesday night, I asked Federighi, Giannandrea, and Joswiak point blank, “So, who's paying who in this deal?” (or something to that effect — transcript isn't done yet), and got nothing more than smiles and shrugs in response. My read on the smiles is that they were smug happy smiles.

Ben Thompson and I recorded today's episode of Dithering — the world's favorite 15-minute podcast — yesterday before Gurman's report dropped, but speculating, we came to the same conclusion, that it seemed likely neither company was paying the other. It makes obvious sense from Apple's perspective. Not so obvious from OpenAI's. But if OpenAI's overriding goal is to cement itself as the leader in world-knowledge LLMs — to become to chatbots what Kleenex is to facial tissues — it makes sense to agree to this just to gain users, some of whom will upgrade to paid accounts. Google, on the other hand, probably wants to be paid by Apple to integrate Gemini. But now Apple can turn to Google — and Anthropic and Mistral and whoever else wants in on this iOS and MacOS integration, like the other default search engines in Safari — and Eddy Cue can tell them “ My offer is this: nothing . Not even the $20,000 for the gaming license, which I would appreciate if you would put up personally.”

Back to Gurman:

ChatGPT will be offered for free on Apple's products, but OpenAI and Apple could still make money by converting free users to paid accounts. OpenAI's subscription plans start at $20 a month — a fee that covers extra features like the ability to analyze data and generate more types of images.

Today, if a user subscribes to OpenAI on an Apple device via the ChatGPT app, the process uses Apple's payment platform, which traditionally gives the iPhone maker a cut.

Not traditionally .总是。 Apple always takes a cut. One of my few regrets from my interview Tuesday night is not thinking to ask, on stage, whether iOS and Mac users will be able to upgrade from free to paid ChatGPT accounts right in Settings, where, I presume, the ChatGPT account sign-in将。 If so, Apple will surely be getting their 30/15 percent slice of that. And what's the alternative? Sending users to OpenAI's website, where Apple would get zilch? That doesn't sound like Apple.

* Bloomberg, of course, is the publication that published “ The Big Hack ” in October 2018 — a sensational story alleging that data centers of Apple, Amazon, and dozens of other companies were compromised by China's intelligence services. The story presented no confirmable evidence at all , was vehemently denied by all companies involved, has not been confirmed by a single other publication (despite much effort to do so), and has been largely discredited by one of Bloomberg's own sources . By all appearances “The Big Hack” was complete bullshit. Yet Bloomberg has issued no correction or retraction, and their only ostensibly substantial follow-up contained not one shred of evidence to back up their allegations. Bloomberg seemingly hopes we'll all just forget about it. I say we do not just forget about it. Everything they publish should be treated with skepticism until they retract “The Big Hack” or provide evidence that any of it was true.

The political theory of Trump's coup attempt is that all that matters is the chieftain. He does not have to win an election, because the chieftain has the right to rule simply because he is the chieftain. Requiring Trump to win an election is thus a provocation. The claim that he should leave office when he loses an election justifies revenge. And of course retribution is Trump's platform.

The legal theory of Trump's coup attempt, made explicit in argument before the Supreme Court, is that the chieftain is immune to law. There is magic around the chieftain's person, such that he need respond only to himself. The words “presidential immunity” are an incantation directed to people in black robes, summoning them to act as the chieftain's shamans and confirm his magical status.

No issue has ever been more important in the history of the United States, and thus, in the history of democracy itself: Donald Trump lost the election in 2020 and tried, ham-fistedly, to spearhead a coup to remain in power by overthrowing the duly elected government of the nation. If he gets another chance by winning in November, the next coup won't be as ham-fisted.

entry.title: 'Apple Aggregates AI'
entry.content:
Ben Thompson:

So what is Apple Intelligence, then? To me the explanation flows directly from Strategy 101: Apple Intelligence is the application of generative AI to use cases and content that Apple is uniquely positioned to provide and access. It is designed, to build on yesterday's Article , to maximize the advantages that Apple has in terms of being the operating system provider on your phone; and, on the other hand, what it is not is any sort of general purpose chatbot: that is where OpenAI comes in — and only there. […]

To put it another way, and in Stratechery terms, Apple is positioning itself as an AI Aggregator: the company owns users and, by extension, generative AI demand by virtue of owning its platforms, and it is deepening its moat through Apple Intelligence, which only Apple can do; that demand is then being brought to bear on suppliers who probably have to eat the costs of getting privileged access to Apple's userbase.

It pains me to admit how great a take this is.搞定了。
